awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Triggered Energy Transfer Chemiluminescence for In Vivo Imaging
awd_abstract_narration:
In this CAREER project funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics & Mechanisms B Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Alexander R. Lippert of the Department of Chemistry at Southern Methodist University is developing responsive glow stick chemistry (chemiluminescence) for biological imaging. The project aims to synthesize and understand specialized molecules that spontaneously emit light in response to biological events. Mastering this fundamental chemical phenomenon found in fireflies and jellyfish provides new methods to measure and visualize the chemistry that lies at the heart of biological processes. The visual appeal of multi-colored chemiluminescence will be used to inspire future generations of students from K-12 to the graduate level with a centralized outreach theme of encouraging scientific creativity through seminars, K-12 research opportunities, and coursework aimed at teaching the creative process in a scientific context.

Triggered chemiluminescence has the potential to dramatically transform biological imaging in wild-type organisms by eliminating autofluorescence, photobleaching, and other issues endemic to traditional fluorescence imaging techniques, but fundamental advances in understanding how molecular structure affects chemiluminescence emission is required. This project aims to synthesize, characterize, and understand new classes of triggered chemiluminescent imaging agents structurally designed to manipulate energy transfer processes. Fundamental questions to be addressed include: 1) How can the energy in a chemiluminescent excited state be efficiently transferred by through-space and through-bond energy transfer mechanisms to enhance luminescence emission? 2) What molecular structures will enable tuning of emission wavelengths for near-infrared and ratiometric readouts? 3) How can chemiluminescence emission be dynamically triggered with spatiotemporally controlled illumination to maximize signal to background in a region of interest?
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report: Energy Transfer Chemiluminescence for In Vivo Imaging

This project has yielded remarkable achievements, advancing the field of chemiluminescence imaging and supporting a new generation of diverse STEM talent. Over the course of this award, all objectives have been successfully completed, leading to new types of chemiluminescence bioimaging agents that use chemistry similar to what happens in glow-sticks and fireflies. The key outcomes and their impact for each objective is stated below:

Objective 1: Development of Ratiometric Chemiluminescence Imaging Agents. The project successfully developed a series of ratiometric chemiluminescence imaging agents for imaging the chemistry inside cancerous tumors, including tumor acidity and oxygenation. These chemiluminescent molecules change color depending on acidity or oxygenation, and this makes it possible to precisely measure these parameters in the growing tumor. Increased acidity and decreased oxygenation signal a particularly aggressive tumor and this could be used to help physicians choose the best therapy for a patient.

Additionally, a series of iridium-based chemiluminescence probes were developed for ratiometric oxygen sensing. Iridium is rarer than gold and has magnificent luminescence properties that the PI was able to harness for chemiluminescence imaging. These probes offer a powerful tool for researchers to study oxygen levels in live mouse models and have the potential to significantly advance our understanding of oxygen dynamics in tissues and organs.

Objective 2: Near-Infrared Chemiluminescence Imaging Scaffolds. The project also led to the development of near-infrared (NIR) chemiluminescence scaffolds. The near-infrared spectrum is on the cusp between visible red light and invisible infrared light. Biological tissue has minimal absorbance in this part of the spectrum, so imaging deep within mammalian tissue can be accomplished. These NIR imaging agents expand the possibilities for studying oxygen levels in living organisms and have important implications for research in fields such as cancer biology and cardiovascular health.

Objective 3: Design of Photocaged and Photoswitchable Chemiluminescence Imaging Agents. In this objective, we have designed glow-stick like molecules that can be activated with light, providing a fantastic technology to control chemiluminescence in space and time, as well as a clever design to transmute light from one form to another. In the pursuit of creating photocaged and photoswitchable chemiluminescence imaging agents, the project explored other innovative strategies to target chemiluminescence imaging agents to specific cells with light, molecular structures, and genetic engineering approaches. These innovative agents are promising tools for a variety of research areas, including cancer treatment and dynamic therapy.

Objective 4: Mentoring and Training of STEM Talent In addition to the scientific advancements, this project has made significant contributions to STEM education and mentoring. The Principal Investigator (PI) has been dedicated to mentoring a large number of undergraduate students from diverse backgrounds. This commitment to diversity and inclusion in STEM is crucial for addressing disparities in the field. Many of these students have gone on to pursue advanced degrees or careers in STEM-related fields, contributing to the diversification and enrichment of the scientific community.

In summary, this project has achieved its objectives, resulting in the development of innovative chemiluminescence imaging agents for various applications. These agents have the potential to transform research in biology, medicine, and other scientific disciplines. Moreover, the commitment to mentoring a diverse group of undergraduate students reflects a dedication to the future of STEM and a commitment to inclusivity in the scientific community. The outcomes of this project have made significant contributions to both scientific knowledge and the development of the next generation of scientists.


Last Modified: 11/04/2023
Modified by: Alexander R Lippert
